speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: SCENE I. Westminster Abbey.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the  Fifth, attended on by Dukes of BEDFORD, Regent of  France; GLOUCESTER, Protector; and EXETER, Earl of WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, Heralds,  and c

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Comets, importing change of times and states,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And with them scourge the bad revolting stars

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: That have consented unto Henry's death!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: England ne'er had a king until his time.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Virtue he had, deserving to command:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His sparking eyes, replete with wrathful fire,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: More dazzled and drove back his enemies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Henry is dead and never shall revive:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Upon a wooden coffin we attend,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And death's dishonourable victory

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: We with our stately presence glorify,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Like captives bound to a triumphant car.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: What! shall we curse the planets of mishap

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That plotted thus our glory's overthrow?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or shall we think the subtle-witted French

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Conjurers and sorcerers, that afraid of him

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: By magic verses have contrived his end?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: He was a king bless'd of the King of kings.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: So dreadful will not be as was his sight.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The church's prayers made him so prosperous.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The church! where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His thread of life had not so soon decay'd:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: None do you like but an effeminate prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom, like a school-boy, you may over-awe.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art protector

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And lookest to command the prince and realm.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: More than God or religious churchmen may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Name not religion, for thou lovest the flesh,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Except it be to pray against thy foes.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Let's to the altar: heralds, wait on us:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Instead of gold, we'll offer up our arms:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Since arms avail not now that Henry's dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Posterity, await for wretched years,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: When at their mothers' moist eyes babes shall suck,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And none but women left to wail the dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Combat with adverse planets in the heavens!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: A far more glorious star thy soul will make

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Than Julius Caesar or bright--

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My honourable lords, health to you all!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of loss, of slaughter and discomfiture:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Guienne, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If Henry were recall'd to life again,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: How were they lost? what treachery was used?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: No treachery; but want of men and money.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That here you maintain several factions,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: You are disputing of your generals:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: One would have lingering wars with little cost;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A third thinks, without expense at all,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Awake, awake, English nobility!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of England's coat one half is cut away.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Me they concern; Regent I am of France.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To weep their intermissive miseries.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter to them another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: France is revolted from the English quite,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Except some petty towns of no import:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We will not fly, but to our enemies' throats.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bedford, if thou be slack, I'll fight it out.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardness?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: An army have I muster'd in my thoughts,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Wherewith already France is overrun.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I must inform you of a dismal fight

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: What! wherein Talbot overcame? is't so?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was o'erthrown:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The circumstance I'll tell you more at large.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Retiring from the siege of Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Having full scarce six thousand in his troop.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By three and twenty thousand of the French

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Was round encompassed and set upon.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: No leisure had he to enrank his men;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He wanted pikes to set before his archers;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They pitched in the ground confusedly,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: More than three hours the fight continued;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Where valiant Talbot above human thought

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here, there, and every where, enraged he flew:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The French exclaim'd, the devil was in arms;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All the whole army stood agazed on him:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And rush'd into the bowels of the battle.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: If Sir John Fastolfe had not play'd the coward:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He, being in the vaward, placed behind

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With purpose to relieve and follow them,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enclosed were they with their enemies:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin's grace,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Whom all France with their chief assembled strength

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Durst not presume to look once in the face.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: For living idly here in pomp and ease,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O no, he lives; but is took prisoner,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And Lord Scales with him and Lord Hungerford:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Farewell, my masters; to my task will I;

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To keep our great Saint George's feast withal:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The English army is grown weak and faint:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: I do remember it; and here take my leave,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To go about my preparation.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To view the artillery and munition;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Being ordain'd his special governor,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And for his safety there I'll best devise.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Each hath his place and function to attend:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: I am left out; for me nothing remains.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But long I will not be Jack out of office:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The king from Eltham I intend to steal

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. France. Before Orleans.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, marching with drum and Soldiers

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: So in the earth, to this day is not known:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Late did he shine upon the English side;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What towns of any moment but we have?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Either they must be dieted like mules

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And have their provender tied to their mouths

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Let's raise the siege: why live we idly here?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear:

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And he may well in fretting spend his gall,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Sound, sound alarum! we will rush on them.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now for the honour of the forlorn French!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Him I forgive my death that killeth me

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: When he sees me go back one foot or fly.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss. Re-enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Who ever saw the like? what men have I!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But that they left me 'midst my enemies.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Salisbury is a desperate homicide;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: He fighteth as one weary of his life.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: The other lords, like lions wanting food,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: England all Olivers and Rowlands bred,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: During the time Edward the Third did reign.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: More truly now may this be verified;

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: For none but Samsons and Goliases

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Lean, raw-boned rascals! who would e'er suppose

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: They had such courage and audacity?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Of old I know them; rather with their teeth

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: I think, by some odd gimmors or device

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Their arms are set like clocks, stiff to strike on;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: By my consent, we'll even let them alone.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Be it so.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appall'd:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Be not dismay'd, for succor is at hand:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: A holy maid hither with me I bring,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Which by a vision sent to her from heaven

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Ordained is to raise this tedious siege

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And drive the English forth the bounds of France.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: What's past and what's to come she can descry.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: For they are certain and unfallible.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Go, call her in.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exit BASTARD OF ORLEANS

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But first, to try her skill,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, with JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Fair maid, is't thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Reignier, is't thou that thinkest to beguile me?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I know thee well, though never seen before.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Be not amazed, there's nothing hid from me:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In private will I talk with thee apart.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: My wit untrain'd in any kind of art.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To shine on my contemptible estate:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And to sun's parching heat display'd my cheeks,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: God's mother deigned to appear to me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And in a vision full of majesty

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Will'd me to leave my base vocation

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And free my country from calamity:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Her aid she promised and assured success:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In complete glory she reveal'd herself;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And, whereas I was black and swart before,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: With those clear rays which she infused on me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That beauty am I bless'd with which you see.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Ask me what question thou canst possible,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And I will answer unpremeditated:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: My courage try by combat, if thou darest,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Resolve on this, thou shalt be fortunate,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Only this proof I'll of thy valour make,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharine's

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: churchyard,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And while I live, I'll ne'er fly from a man.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here they fight, and JOAN LA PUCELLE overcomes

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Stay, stay thy hands! thou art an Amazon

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Christ's mother helps me, else I were too weak.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Whoe'er helps thee, 'tis thou that must help me:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Impatiently I burn with thy desire;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Let me thy servant and not sovereign be:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: 'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I must not yield to any rites of love,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For my profession's sacred from above:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When I have chased all thy foes from hence,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then will I think upon a recompense.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: He may mean more than we poor men do know:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My lord, where are you? what devise you on?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Shall we give over Orleans, or no?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Why, no, I say, distrustful recreants!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What she says I'll confirm: we'll fight it out.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Assign'd am I to be the English scourge.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This night the siege assuredly I'll raise:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Expect Saint Martin's summer, halcyon days,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Since I have entered into these wars.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Glory is like a circle in the water,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: With Henry's death the English circle ends;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dispersed are the glories it included.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now am I like that proud insulting ship

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thou with an eagle art inspired then.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Helen, the mother of great Constantine,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters, were like thee.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Bright star of Venus, fall'n down on the earth,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: How may I reverently worship thee enough?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Presently we'll try: come, let's away about it:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE III. London. Before the Tower.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, with his Serving-men in blue coats

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am come to survey the Tower this day:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since Henry's death, I fear, there is conveyance.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where be these warders, that they wait not here?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that calls.

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: [Within]  Who's there that knocks so imperiously?

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: First Serving-Man It is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

speaker: Second Warder
text_entry: [Within]  Whoe'er he be, you may not be let in.

speaker: Second Warder
text_entry: First Serving-Man Villains, answer you so the lord protector?

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: [Within]  The Lord protect him! so we answer him:

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: We do no otherwise than we are will'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who willed you? or whose will stands but mine?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There's none protector of the realm but I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Break up the gates, I'll be your warrantize.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Gloucester's men rush at the Tower Gates, and WOODVILE the Lieutenant speaks within

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: What noise is this? what traitors have we here?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter.

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: Have patience, noble duke; I may not open;

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: The Cardinal of Winchester forbids:

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: From him I have express commandment

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Faint-hearted Woodvile, prizest him 'fore me?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne'er could brook?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art no friend to God or to the king:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates, or I'll shut thee out shortly.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Serving-Men Open the gates unto the lord protector,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or we'll burst them open, if that you come not quickly.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter to the Protector at the Tower Gates BISHOP OF WINCHESTER and his men in tawny coats

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: How now, ambitious Humphry! what means this?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Peel'd priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: I do, thou most usurping proditor,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And not protector, of the king or realm.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou that contrivedst to murder our dead lord;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not slay thee, but I'll drive thee back:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy scarlet robes as a child's bearing-cloth

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll use to carry thee out of this place.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Do what thou darest; I beard thee to thy face.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What! am I dared and bearded to my face?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Draw, men, for all this privileged place;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal's hat:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In spite of pope or dignities of church,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here by the cheeks I'll drag thee up and down.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the pope.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Winchester goose, I cry, a rope! a rope!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thee I'll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep's array.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Out, tawny coats! out, scarlet hypocrite!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here GLOUCESTER's men beat out BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER's men, and enter in the hurly- burly the Mayor of London and his Officers

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Peace, mayor! thou know'st little of my wrongs:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: One that still motions war and never peace,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: O'ercharging your free purses with large fines,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: That seeks to overthrow religion,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Because he is protector of the realm,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And would have armour here out of the Tower,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To crown himself king and suppress the prince.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here they skirmish again

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: But to make open proclamation:

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Come, officer; as loud as e'er thou canst,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Cry.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: All manner of men assembled here in arms this day

speaker: Officer
text_entry: against God's peace and the king's, we charge and

speaker: Officer
text_entry: command you, in his highness' name, to repair to

speaker: Officer
text_entry: your several dwelling-places; and not to wear,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: henceforward, upon pain of death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cardinal, I'll be no breaker of the law:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But we shall meet, and break our minds at large.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, we will meet; to thy cost, be sure:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Thy heart-blood I will have for this day's work.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: I'll call for clubs, if you will not away.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: This cardinal's more haughty than the devil.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Mayor, farewell: thou dost but what thou mayst.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: For I intend to have it ere long.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Exeunt, severally, GLOUCESTER and BISHOP OF WINCHESTER with their Serving-men

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: See the coast clear'd, and then we will depart.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: I myself fight not once in forty year.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: SCENE IV. Orleans.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Enter, on the walls, a Master Gunner and his Boy

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Master-Gunner Sirrah, thou know'st how Orleans is besieged,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And how the English have the suburbs won.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Howe'er unfortunate I miss'd my aim.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Master-Gunner But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me:

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Chief master-gunner am I of this town;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Something I must do to procure me grace.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: The prince's espials have informed me

speaker: Boy
text_entry: How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars

speaker: Boy
text_entry: In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And thence discover how with most advantage

speaker: Boy
text_entry: They may vex us with shot, or with assault.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: To intercept this inconvenience,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have placed;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And even these three days have I watch'd,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: If I could see them.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And thou shalt find me at the governor's.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Father, I warrant you; take you no care;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I'll never trouble you, if I may spy them.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter, on the turrets, SALISBURY and TALBOT, GLANSDALE, GARGRAVE, and others

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd!

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: How wert thou handled being prisoner?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Or by what means got'st thou to be released?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Discourse, I prithee, on this turret's top.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For him was I exchanged and ransomed.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But with a baser man of arms by far

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Once in contempt they would have barter'd me:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Which I, disdaining, scorn'd; and craved death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Rather than I would be so vile esteem'd.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In fine, redeem'd I was as I desired.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whom with my bare fists I would execute,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If I now had him brought into my power.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In open market-place produced they me,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To be a public spectacle to all:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here, said they, is the terror of the French,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The scarecrow that affrights our children so.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then broke I from the officers that led me,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And with my nails digg'd stones out of the ground,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To hurl at the beholders of my shame:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My grisly countenance made others fly;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: None durst come near for fear of sudden death.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In iron walls they deem'd me not secure;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That they supposed I could rend bars of steel,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And spurn in pieces posts of adamant:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That walked about me every minute-while;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And if I did but stir out of my bed,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter the Boy with a linstock

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But we will be revenged sufficiently

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Now it is supper-time in Orleans:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Here, through this grate, I count each one

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Let me have your express opinions

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Where is best place to make our battery next.

speaker: GARGRAVE
text_entry: I think, at the north gate; for there stand lords.

speaker: GLANSDALE
text_entry: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For aught I see, this city must be famish'd,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here they shoot. SALISBURY and GARGRAVE fall

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

speaker: GARGRAVE
text_entry: O Lord, have mercy on me, woful man!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How farest thou, mirror of all martial men?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That hath contrived this woful tragedy!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Yet livest thou, Salisbury? though thy speech doth fail,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: One eye thou hast, to look to heaven for grace:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou shalt not die whiles--

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As who should say 'When I am dead and gone,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Remember to avenge me on the French.'

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Plantagenet, I will; and like thee, Nero,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wretched shall France be only in my name.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What stir is this? what tumult's in the heavens?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle join'd,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A holy prophetess new risen up,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Frenchmen, I'll be a Salisbury to you:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pucelle or puzzel, dolphin or dogfish,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Your hearts I'll stamp out with my horse's heels,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Convey me Salisbury into his tent,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And then we'll try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum. Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE V. The same.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here an alarum again: and TALBOT pursueth the  DAUPHIN, and driveth him: then enter JOAN LA  PUCELLE, driving Englishmen before her, and exit after them then re-enter TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A woman clad in armour chaseth them.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Re-enter JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here, here she comes. I'll have a bout with thee;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Devil or devil's dam, I'll conjure thee:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And straightway give thy soul to him thou servest.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace thee.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here they fight

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: They fight again

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Talbot, farewell; thy hour is not yet come:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I must go victual Orleans forthwith.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: A short alarum; then enter the town with soldiers

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: O'ertake me, if thou canst; I scorn thy strength.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Help Salisbury to make his testament:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This day is ours, as many more shall be.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I know not where I am, nor what I do;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A witch, by fear, not force, like Hannibal,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Are from their hives and houses driven away.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: They call'd us for our fierceness English dogs;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A short alarum

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hark, countrymen! either renew the fight,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or tear the lions out of England's coat;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions' stead:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or horse or oxen from the leopard,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum. Here another skirmish

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It will not be: retire into your trenches:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You all consented unto Salisbury's death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pucelle is enter'd into Orleans,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In spite of us or aught that we could do.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, would I were to die with Salisbury!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exit TALBOT. Alarum; retreat; flourish

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter, on the walls, JOAN LA PUCELLE, CHARLES, REIGNIER, ALENCON, and Soldiers

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Advance our waving colours on the walls;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Rescued is Orleans from the English

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Thus Joan la Pucelle hath perform'd her word.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Divinest creature, Astraea's daughter,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: How shall I honour thee for this success?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That one day bloom'd and fruitful were the next.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Recover'd is the town of Orleans:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: More blessed hap did ne'er befall our state.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Why ring not out the bells aloud throughout the town?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And feast and banquet in the open streets,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To celebrate the joy that God hath given us.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: All France will be replete with mirth and joy,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: When they shall hear how we have play'd the men.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: 'Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: For which I will divide my crown with her,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And all the priests and friars in my realm

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Shall in procession sing her endless praise.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: A statelier pyramis to her I'll rear

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Than Rhodope's or Memphis' ever was:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: In memory of her when she is dead,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Her ashes, in an urn more precious

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Than the rich-jewel'd of Darius,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Transported shall be at high festivals

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Before the kings and queens of France.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No longer on Saint Denis will we cry,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But Joan la Pucelle shall be France's saint.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Come in, and let us banquet royally,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: After this golden day of victory.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE I. Before Orleans.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter a Sergeant of a band with two Sentinels

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant:

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: If any noise or soldier you perceive

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Near to the walls, by some apparent sign

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Sergeant, you shall.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Exit Sergeant

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Thus are poor servitors,

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: When others sleep upon their quiet beds,

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Constrain'd to watch in darkness, rain and cold.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, and Forces, with scaling-ladders, their drums beating a dead march

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: By whose approach the regions of Artois,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wallon and Picardy are friends to us,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Having all day caroused and banqueted:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Embrace we then this opportunity

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As fitting best to quittance their deceit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Despairing of his own arm's fortitude,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To join with witches and the help of hell!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Traitors have never other company.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A maid, they say.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: A maid! and be so martial!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: If underneath the standard of the French

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: She carry armour as she hath begun.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Well, let them practise and converse with spirits:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: God is our fortress, in whose conquering name

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not all together: better far, I guess,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That we do make our entrance several ways;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That, if it chance the one of us do fail,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The other yet may rise against their force.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Agreed: I'll to yond corner.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And I to this.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Of English Henry, shall this night appear

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How much in duty I am bound to both.

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: Arm! arm! the enemy doth make assault!

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: Cry: 'St. George,' 'A Talbot.'

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: The French leap over the walls in their shirts.  Enter, several ways, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, half ready, and half unready

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: How now, my lords! what, all unready so?

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Unready! ay, and glad we 'scaped so well.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: 'Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Hearing alarums at our chamber-doors.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Of all exploits since first I follow'd arms,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Ne'er heard I of a warlike enterprise

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: More venturous or desperate than this.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: If not of hell, the heavens, sure, favour him.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Here cometh Charles: I marvel how he sped.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Enter CHARLES and JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Make us partakers of a little gain,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That now our loss might be ten times so much?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: At all times will you have my power alike?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Sleeping or waking must I still prevail,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This sudden mischief never could have fall'n.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Duke of Alencon, this was your default,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That, being captain of the watch to-night,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Did look no better to that weighty charge.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Had all your quarters been as safely kept

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: As that whereof I had the government,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Mine was secure.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And so was mine, my lord.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And, for myself, most part of all this night,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Within her quarter and mine own precinct

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: I was employ'd in passing to and fro,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: About relieving of the sentinels:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Then how or which way should they first break in?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Question, my lords, no further of the case,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: How or which way: 'tis sure they found some place

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And now there rests no other shift but this;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To gather our soldiers, scatter'd and dispersed,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And lay new platforms to endamage them.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier, crying 'A  Talbot! a Talbot!' They fly, leaving their clothes behind

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: I'll be so bold to take what they have left.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword;

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: For I have loaden me with many spoils,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Using no other weapon but his name.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: SCENE II. Orleans. Within the town.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, a Captain, and others

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: The day begins to break, and night is fled,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whose pitchy mantle over-veil'd the earth.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Here sound retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Retreat sounded

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And here advance it in the market-place,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The middle centre of this cursed town.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For every drop of blood was drawn from him,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And that hereafter ages may behold

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What ruin happen'd in revenge of him,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Within their chiefest temple I'll erect

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interr'd:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Upon the which, that every one may read,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall be engraved the sack of Orleans,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The treacherous manner of his mournful death

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And what a terror he had been to France.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Nor any of his false confederates.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: 'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: They did amongst the troops of armed men

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Myself, as far as I could well discern

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: For smoke and dusky vapours of the night,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: When arm in arm they both came swiftly running,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That could not live asunder day or night.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: After that things are set in order here,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: We'll follow them with all the power we have.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All hail, my lords! which of this princely train

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Call ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: So much applauded through the realm of France?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here is the Talbot: who would speak with him?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With modesty admiring thy renown,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To visit her poor castle where she lies,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That she may boast she hath beheld the man

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Is it even so? Nay, then, I see our wars

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: When ladies crave to be encounter'd with.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Could not prevail with all their oratory,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Yet hath a woman's kindness over-ruled:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And therefore tell her I return great thanks,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And in submission will attend on her.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Will not your honours bear me company?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: No, truly; it is more than manners will:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And I have heard it said, unbidden guests

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Are often welcomest when they are gone.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Well then, alone, since there's no remedy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I mean to prove this lady's courtesy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Come hither, captain.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You perceive my mind?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Captain
text_entry: SCENE III. Auvergne. The COUNTESS's castle.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter

speaker: Captain
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Porter, remember what I gave in charge;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Madam, I will.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Porter
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: The plot is laid: if all things fall out right,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I shall as famous be by this exploit

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And his achievements of no less account:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To give their censure of these rare reports.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Enter Messenger and TALBOT

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Madam,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: According as your ladyship desired,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And he is welcome. What! is this the man?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Madam, it is.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Is this the scourge of France?

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Is this the Talbot, so much fear'd abroad

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: That with his name the mothers still their babes?

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I see report is fabulous and false:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I thought I should have seen some Hercules,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: A second Hector, for his grim aspect,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf!

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Should strike such terror to his enemies.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But since your ladyship is not at leisure,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I'll sort some other time to visit you.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I go to certify her Talbot's here.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Re-enter Porter with keys

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Prisoner! to whom?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To me, blood-thirsty lord;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And for that cause I trained thee to my house.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: For in my gallery thy picture hangs:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: But now the substance shall endure the like,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: That hast by tyranny these many years

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Wasted our country, slain our citizens

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ha, ha, ha!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Laughest thou, wretch? thy mirth shall turn to moan.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whereon to practise your severity.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Why, art not thou the man?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I am indeed.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Then have I substance too.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: No, no, I am but shadow of myself:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You are deceived, my substance is not here;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For what you see is but the smallest part

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And least proportion of humanity:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It is of such a spacious lofty pitch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Your roof were not sufficient to contain't.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: He will be here, and yet he is not here:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: How can these contrarieties agree?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That will I show you presently.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How say you, madam? are you now persuaded

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That Talbot is but shadow of himself?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Razeth your cities and subverts your towns

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And in a moment makes them desolate.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And more than may be gather'd by thy shape.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: For I am sorry that with reverence

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I did not entertain thee as thou art.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be not dismay'd, fair lady; nor misconstrue

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The outward composition of his body.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What you have done hath not offended me;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Nor other satisfaction do I crave,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But only, with your patience, that we may

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Taste of your wine and see what cates you have;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: With all my heart, and think me honoured

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To feast so great a warrior in my house.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The Temple-garden.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Enter the Earls of SOMERSET, SUFFOLK, and WARWICK; RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another Lawyer

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Within the Temple-hall we were too loud;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The garden here is more convenient.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Faith, I have been a truant in the law,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And never yet could frame my will to it;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And therefore frame the law unto my will.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two blades, which bears the better temper:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two horses, which doth bear him best;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But in these nice sharp quillets of the law,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: The truth appears so naked on my side

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That any purblind eye may find it out.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And on my side it is so well apparell'd,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: So clear, so shining and so evident

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Let him that is a true-born gentleman

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And stands upon the honour of his birth,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: If he suppose that I have pleaded truth,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: But dare maintain the party of the truth,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I love no colours, and without all colour

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of base insinuating flattery

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And say withal I think he held the right.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Till you conclude that he upon whose side

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: The fewest roses are cropp'd from the tree

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And I.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Then for the truth and plainness of the case.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Lest bleeding you do paint the white rose red

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And fall on my side so, against your will.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: If I my lord, for my opinion bleed,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And keep me on the side where still I am.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Well, well, come on: who else?

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: Unless my study and my books be false,

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: The argument you held was wrong in you:

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: To SOMERSET

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Here in my scabbard, meditating that

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For pale they look with fear, as witnessing

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: The truth on our side.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: No, Plantagenet,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: 'Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Well, I'll find friends to wear my bleeding roses,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That shall maintain what I have said is true,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Away, away, good William de la Pole!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, by God's will, thou wrong'st him, Somerset;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Third son to the third Edward King of England:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: He bears him on the place's privilege,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or durst not, for his craven heart, say thus.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: By him that made me, I'll maintain my words

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: On any plot of ground in Christendom.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: For treason executed in our late king's days?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And, by his treason, stand'st not thou attainted,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: My father was attached, not attainted,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Condemn'd to die for treason, but no traitor;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Were growing time once ripen'd to my will.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For your partaker Pole and you yourself,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: I'll note you in my book of memory,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: To scourge you for this apprehension:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Look to it well and say you are well warn'd.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And know us by these colours for thy foes,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Will I for ever and my faction wear,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Until it wither with me to my grave

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or flourish to the height of my degree.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Go forward and be choked with thy ambition!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And so farewell until I meet thee next.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This blot that they object against your house

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall be wiped out in the next parliament

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Call'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And if thou be not then created York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I will not live to be accounted Warwick.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Meantime, in signal of my love to thee,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Against proud Somerset and William Pole,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Will I upon thy party wear this rose:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Grown to this faction in the Temple-garden,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall send between the red rose and the white

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: And so will I.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thanks, gentle sir.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Come, let us four to dinner: I dare say

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: This quarrel will drink blood another day.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: SCENE V. The Tower of London.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Enter MORTIMER, brought in a chair, and Gaolers

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Even like a man new haled from the rack,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: So fare my limbs with long imprisonment.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And these grey locks, the pursuivants of death,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Nestor-like aged in an age of care,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Weak shoulders, overborne with burthening grief,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And pithless arms, like to a wither'd vine

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That droops his sapless branches to the ground;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Unable to support this lump of clay,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Swift-winged with desire to get a grave,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: As witting I no other comfort have.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

speaker: First Gaoler
