text_entry: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come:

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber;

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: And answer was return'd that he will come.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Enough: my soul shall then be satisfied.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Poor gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Before whose glory I was great in arms,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: This loathsome sequestration have I had:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And even since then hath Richard been obscured,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Deprived of honour and inheritance.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But now the arbitrator of despairs,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Just death, kind umpire of men's miseries,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I would his troubles likewise were expired,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That so he might recover what was lost.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Enter RICHARD PLANTAGENET

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And in his bosom spend my latter gasp:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And now declare, sweet stem from York's great stock,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Why didst thou say, of late thou wert despised?

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And, in that ease, I'll tell thee my disease.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: This day, in argument upon a case,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Among which terms he used his lavish tongue

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And did upbraid me with my father's death:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Else with the like I had requited him.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Therefore, good uncle, for my father's sake,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In honour of a true Plantagenet

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And for alliance sake, declare the cause

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That cause, fair nephew, that imprison'd me

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And hath detain'd me all my flowering youth

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Was cursed instrument of his decease.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Discover more at large what cause that was,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I will, if that my fading breath permit

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And death approach not ere my tale be done.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward's son,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: The first-begotten and the lawful heir,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Of Edward king, the third of that descent:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: During whose reign the Percies of the north,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Finding his usurpation most unjust,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Endeavor'd my advancement to the throne:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: The reason moved these warlike lords to this

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Was, for that--young King Richard thus removed,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Leaving no heir begotten of his body--

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I was the next by birth and parentage;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: For by my mother I derived am

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From Lionel Duke of Clarence, the third son

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: To King Edward the Third; whereas he

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Being but fourth of that heroic line.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But mark: as in this haughty attempt

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: They laboured to plant the rightful heir,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I lost my liberty and they their lives.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Long after this, when Henry the Fifth,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thy father, Earl of Cambridge, then derived

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Marrying my sister that thy mother was,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Again in pity of my hard distress

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Levied an army, weening to redeem

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And have install'd me in the diadem:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: In whom the tide rested, were suppress'd.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Of which, my lord, your honour is the last.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: True; and thou seest that I no issue have

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And that my fainting words do warrant death;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But yet be wary in thy studious care.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: But yet, methinks, my father's execution

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With silence, nephew, be thou politic:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And like a mountain, not to be removed.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But now thy uncle is removing hence:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: As princes do their courts, when they are cloy'd

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With long continuance in a settled place.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: O, uncle, would some part of my young years

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Might but redeem the passage of your age!

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Only give order for my funeral:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Dies

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul!

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And like a hermit overpass'd thy days.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And what I do imagine let that rest.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Will see his burial better than his life.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exeunt Gaolers, bearing out the body of MORTIMER

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Choked with ambition of the meaner sort:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Which Somerset hath offer'd to my house:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: I doubt not but with honour to redress;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And therefore haste I to the parliament,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Either to be restored to my blood,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or make my ill the advantage of my good.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, EXETER, GLOUCESTER,  WARWICK, SOMERSET, and SUFFOLK; the BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER, RICHARD PLANTAGENET, and others.  GLOUCESTER offers to put up a bill; BISHOP OF WINCHESTER snatches it, and tears it

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Comest thou with deep premeditated lines,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: With written pamphlets studiously devised,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Humphrey of Gloucester? If thou canst accuse,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or aught intend'st to lay unto my charge,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Do it without invention, suddenly;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As I with sudden and extemporal speech

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Presumptuous priest! this place commands my patience,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonour'd me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Think not, although in writing I preferr'd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That therefore I have forged, or am not able

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickedness,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy lewd, pestiferous and dissentious pranks,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As very infants prattle of thy pride.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art a most pernicious usurer,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Forward by nature, enemy to peace;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A man of thy profession and degree;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And for thy treachery, what's more manifest?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As well at London bridge as at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The king, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From envious malice of thy swelling heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, I do defy thee. Lords, vouchsafe

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To give me hearing what I shall reply.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: If I were covetous, ambitious or perverse,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As he will have me, how am I so poor?

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or how haps it I seek not to advance

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling?

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And for dissension, who preferreth peace

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: More than I do?--except I be provoked.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: No, my good lords, it is not that offends;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: It is not that that hath incensed the duke:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: It is, because no one should sway but he;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: No one but he should be about the king;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And that engenders thunder in his breast

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And makes him roar these accusations forth.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But he shall know I am as good--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As good!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou bastard of my grandfather!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But one imperious in another's throne?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Am I not protector, saucy priest?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And am not I a prelate of the church?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And useth it to patronage his theft.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Unreverent Gloster!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art reverent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Rome shall remedy this.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Roam thither, then.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, see the bishop be not overborne.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Methinks my lord should be religious

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And know the office that belongs to such.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Methinks his lordship should be humbler;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: it fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Yes, when his holy state is touch'd so near.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: State holy or unhallow'd, what of that?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Is not his grace protector to the king?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: [Aside]  Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Lest it be said 'Speak, sirrah, when you should;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?'

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The special watchmen of our English weal,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I would prevail, if prayers might prevail,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To join your hearts in love and amity.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, what a scandal is it to our crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That two such noble peers as ye should jar!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Civil dissension is a viperous worm

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A noise within, 'Down with the tawny-coats!'

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What tumult's this?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: An uproar, I dare warrant,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Begun through malice of the bishop's men.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A noise again, 'Stones! stones!' Enter Mayor

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Pity the city of London, pity us!

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: The bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Forbidden late to carry any weapon,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Have fill'd their pockets full of pebble stones

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And banding themselves in contrary parts

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Do pelt so fast at one another's pate

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: That many have their giddy brains knock'd out:

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Our windows are broke down in every street

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And we for fear compell'd to shut our shops.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Enter Serving-men, in skirmish, with bloody pates

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To hold your slaughtering hands and keep the peace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First Serving-man Nay, if we be forbidden stones,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We'll fall to it with our teeth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Second Serving-man Do what ye dare, we are as resolute.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Skirmish again

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You of my household, leave this peevish broil

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And set this unaccustom'd fight aside.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Third Serving-man My lord, we know your grace to be a man

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Just and upright; and, for your royal birth,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Inferior to none but to his majesty:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And ere that we will suffer such a prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So kind a father of the commonweal,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We and our wives and children all will fight

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: First Serving-man Ay, and the very parings of our nails

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Begin again

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stay, stay, I say!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if you love me, as you say you do,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My sighs and tears and will not once relent?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Who should be pitiful, if you be not?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or who should study to prefer a peace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Yield, my lord protector; yield, Winchester;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Except you mean with obstinate repulse

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You see what mischief and what murder too

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath been enacted through your enmity;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then be at peace except ye thirst for blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Compassion on the king commands me stoop;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or I would see his heart out, ere the priest

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Should ever get that privilege of me.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the duke

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath banish'd moody discontented fury,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As by his smoothed brows it doth appear:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why look you still so stern and tragical?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That malice was a great and grievous sin;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And will not you maintain the thing you teach,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But prove a chief offender in the same?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Sweet king! the bishop hath a kindly gird.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For shame, my lord of Winchester, relent!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What, shall a child instruct you what to do?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See here, my friends and loving countrymen,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This token serveth for a flag of truce

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Betwixt ourselves and all our followers:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So help me God, as I dissemble not!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  So help me God, as I intend it not!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How joyful am I made by this contract!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Away, my masters! trouble us no more;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But join in friendship, as your lords have done.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First Serving-man Content: I'll to the surgeon's.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Second Serving-man And so will I.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Third Serving-man And I will see what physic the tavern affords.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt Serving-men, Mayor,  and c

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: We do exhibit to your majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick: or sweet prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if your grace mark every circumstance,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You have great reason to do Richard right;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Especially for those occasions

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At Eltham Place I told your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And those occasions, uncle, were of force:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That Richard be restored to his blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Let Richard be restored to his blood;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So shall his father's wrongs be recompensed.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If Richard will be true, not that alone

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But all the whole inheritance I give

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That doth belong unto the house of York,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From whence you spring by lineal descent.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thy humble servant vows obedience

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And humble service till the point of death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stoop then and set your knee against my foot;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, in reguerdon of that duty done,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I gird thee with the valiant sword of York:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Rise Richard, like a true Plantagenet,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And rise created princely Duke of York.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall!

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And as my duty springs, so perish they

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That grudge one thought against your majesty!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: [Aside]  Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now will it best avail your majesty

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To cross the seas and to be crown'd in France:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The presence of a king engenders love

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As it disanimates his enemies.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your ships already are in readiness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but EXETER

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Ay, we may march in England or in France,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Not seeing what is likely to ensue.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This late dissension grown betwixt the peers

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Burns under feigned ashes of forged love

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And will at last break out into a flame:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: As fester'd members rot but by degree,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: So will this base and envious discord breed.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And now I fear that fatal prophecy

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Was in the mouth of every sucking babe;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That Henry born at Monmouth should win all

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And Henry born at Windsor lose all:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: His days may finish ere that hapless time.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. France. Before Rouen.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE disguised, with four Soldiers with sacks upon their backs

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: These are the city gates, the gates of Rouen,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Through which our policy must make a breach:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Take heed, be wary how you place your words;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Talk like the vulgar sort of market men

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That come to gather money for their corn.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If we have entrance, as I hope we shall,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And that we find the slothful watch but weak,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I'll by a sign give notice to our friends,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And we be lords and rulers over Rouen;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Therefore we'll knock.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Knocks

speaker: Watch
text_entry: [Within]  Qui est la?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Paysans, pauvres gens de France;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.

speaker: Watch
text_entry: Enter, go in; the market bell is rung.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now, Rouen, I'll shake thy bulwarks to the ground.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, REIGNIER, and forces

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Saint Denis bless this happy stratagem!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And once again we'll sleep secure in Rouen.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Here enter'd Pucelle and her practisants;

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Now she is there, how will she specify

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Where is the best and safest passage in?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Which, once discern'd, shows that her meaning is,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: No way to that, for weakness, which she enter'd.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE on the top, thrusting out a torch burning

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Behold, this is the happy wedding torch

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That joineth Rouen unto her countrymen,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But burning fatal to the Talbotites!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: See, noble Charles, the beacon of our friend;

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: The burning torch in yonder turret stands.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now shine it like a comet of revenge,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: A prophet to the fall of all our foes!

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Defer no time, delays have dangerous ends;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Enter, and cry 'The Dauphin!' presently,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And then do execution on the watch.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Alarum. Exeunt

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: An alarum. Enter TALBOT in an excursion

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If Talbot but survive thy treachery.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pucelle, that witch, that damned sorceress,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hath wrought this hellish mischief unawares,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That hardly we escaped the pride of France.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: An alarum: excursions. BEDFORD, brought in sick  in a chair. Enter TALBOT and BURGUNDY without:  within JOAN LA PUCELLE, CHARLES, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, on the walls

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Good morrow, gallants! want ye corn for bread?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Before he'll buy again at such a rate:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: 'Twas full of darnel; do you like the taste?

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Scoff on, vile fiend and shameless courtezan!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Your grace may starve perhaps before that time.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: O, let no words, but deeds, revenge this treason!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: What will you do, good grey-beard? break a lance,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And run a tilt at death within a chair?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Foul fiend of France, and hag of all despite,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Encompass'd with thy lustful paramours!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And twit with cowardice a man half dead?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Damsel, I'll have a bout with you again,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or else let Talbot perish with this shame.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Are ye so hot, sir? yet, Pucelle, hold thy peace;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If Talbot do but thunder, rain will follow.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The English whisper together in council

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: God speed the parliament! who shall be the speaker?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Dare ye come forth and meet us in the field?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Belike your lordship takes us then for fools,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To try if that our own be ours or no.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I speak not to that railing Hecate,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But unto thee, Alencon, and the rest;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Will ye, like soldiers, come and fight it out?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Signior, no.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Signior, hang! base muleters of France!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Like peasant foot-boys do they keep the walls

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Away, captains! let's get us from the walls;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For Talbot means no goodness by his looks.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: God be wi' you, my lord! we came but to tell you

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That we are here.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exeunt from the walls

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And there will we be too, ere it be long,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or else reproach be Talbot's greatest fame!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Vow, Burgundy, by honour of thy house,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Prick'd on by public wrongs sustain'd in France,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Either to get the town again or die:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And I, as sure as English Henry lives

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And as his father here was conqueror,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As sure as in this late-betrayed town

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Great Coeur-de-lion's heart was buried,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: So sure I swear to get the town or die.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: My vows are equal partners with thy vows.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, ere we go, regard this dying prince,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The valiant Duke of Bedford. Come, my lord,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: We will bestow you in some better place,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Fitter for sickness and for crazy age.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Lord Talbot, do not so dishonour me:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Here will I sit before the walls of Rouen

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And will be partner of your weal or woe.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Not to be gone from hence; for once I read

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: That stout Pendragon in his litter sick

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Came to the field and vanquished his foes:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Because I ever found them as myself.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Undaunted spirit in a dying breast!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then be it so: heavens keep old Bedford safe!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And now no more ado, brave Burgundy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But gather we our forces out of hand

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And set upon our boasting enemy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt all but BEDFORD and Attendants

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: An alarum: excursions. Enter FASTOLFE and a Captain

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Whither away, Sir John Fastolfe, in such haste?

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: Whither away! to save myself by flight:

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: We are like to have the overthrow again.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: What! will you fly, and leave Lord Talbot?

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: Ay,

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: All the Talbots in the world, to save my life!

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Cowardly knight! ill fortune follow thee!

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Retreat: excursions. JOAN LA PUCELLE, ALENCON, and CHARLES fly

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: For I have seen our enemies' overthrow.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: What is the trust or strength of foolish man?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: They that of late were daring with their scoffs

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: BEDFORD dies, and is carried in by two in his chair

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: An alarum. Re-enter TALBOT, BURGUNDY, and the rest

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lost, and recover'd in a day again!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This is a double honour, Burgundy:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Yet heavens have glory for this victory!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Warlike and martial Talbot, Burgundy

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Enshrines thee in his heart and there erects

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Thy noble deeds as valour's monuments.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thanks, gentle duke. But where is Pucelle now?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I think her old familiar is asleep:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now where's the Bastard's braves, and Charles his gleeks?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What, all amort? Rouen hangs her head for grief

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That such a valiant company are fled.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now will we take some order in the town,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Placing therein some expert officers,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And then depart to Paris to the king,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For there young Henry with his nobles lie.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: What wills Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But yet, before we go, let's not forget

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The noble Duke of Bedford late deceased,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But see his exequies fulfill'd in Rouen:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A braver soldier never couched lance,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A gentler heart did never sway in court;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But kings and mightiest potentates must die,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For that's the end of human misery.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE III. The plains near Rouen.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, JOAN LA PUCELLE, and forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dismay not, princes, at this accident,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Nor grieve that Rouen is so recovered:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Care is no cure, but rather corrosive,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For things that are not to be remedied.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And like a peacock sweep along his tail;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: We'll pull his plumes and take away his train,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If Dauphin and the rest will be but ruled.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: We have been guided by thee hitherto,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And of thy cunning had no diffidence:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Search out thy wit for secret policies,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And we will make thee famous through the world.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: We'll set thy statue in some holy place,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And have thee reverenced like a blessed saint:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By fair persuasions mix'd with sugar'd words

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: We will entice the Duke of Burgundy

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To leave the Talbot and to follow us.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: France were no place for Henry's warriors;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Nor should that nation boast it so with us,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But be extirped from our provinces.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: For ever should they be expulsed from France

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And not have title of an earldom here.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Your honours shall perceive how I will work

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To bring this matter to the wished end.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Drum sounds afar off

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Hark! by the sound of drum you may perceive

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here sound an English march. Enter, and pass over at a distance, TALBOT and his forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: There goes the Talbot, with his colours spread,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And all the troops of English after him.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: French march. Enter BURGUNDY and forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now in the rearward comes the duke and his:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Fortune in favour makes him lag behind.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Summon a parley; we will talk with him.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Trumpets sound a parley

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The princely Charles of France, thy countryman.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: What say'st thou, Charles? for I am marching hence.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Speak, Pucelle, and enchant him with thy words.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Stay, let thy humble handmaid speak to thee.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Speak on; but be not over-tedious.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Look on thy country, look on fertile France,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And see the cities and the towns defaced

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By wasting ruin of the cruel foe.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: As looks the mother on her lowly babe

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When death doth close his tender dying eyes,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: See, see the pining malady of France;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Behold the wounds, the most unnatural wounds,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which thou thyself hast given her woful breast.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: O, turn thy edged sword another way;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: One drop of blood drawn from thy country's bosom

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Should grieve thee more than streams of foreign gore:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Return thee therefore with a flood of tears,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And wash away thy country's stained spots.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Either she hath bewitch'd me with her words,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Or nature makes me suddenly relent.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Besides, all French and France exclaims on thee,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Doubting thy birth and lawful progeny.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Who joint'st thou with but with a lordly nation

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That will not trust thee but for profit's sake?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When Talbot hath set footing once in France

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And fashion'd thee that instrument of ill,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Who then but English Henry will be lord

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And thou be thrust out like a fugitive?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Call we to mind, and mark but this for proof,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Was not the Duke of Orleans thy foe?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And was he not in England prisoner?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But when they heard he was thine enemy,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They set him free without his ransom paid,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In spite of Burgundy and all his friends.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: See, then, thou fight'st against thy countrymen

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And joint'st with them will be thy slaughtermen.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Come, come, return; return, thou wandering lord:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Charles and the rest will take thee in their arms.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: I am vanquished; these haughty words of hers

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Have batter'd me like roaring cannon-shot,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And made me almost yield upon my knees.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Forgive me, country, and sweet countrymen,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And, lords, accept this hearty kind embrace:

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: My forces and my power of men are yours:

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: So farewell, Talbot; I'll no longer trust thee.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: [Aside]  Done like a Frenchman: turn, and turn again!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Welcome, brave duke! thy friendship makes us fresh.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And doth beget new courage in our breasts.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Pucelle hath bravely play'd her part in this,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And doth deserve a coronet of gold.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now let us on, my lords, and join our powers,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And seek how we may prejudice the foe.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE IV. Paris. The palace.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER, YORK, SUFFOLK, SOMERSET, WARWICK,  EXETER, VERNON BASSET, and others. To them with his Soldiers, TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My gracious prince, and honourable peers,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hearing of your arrival in this realm,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I have awhile given truce unto my wars,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To do my duty to my sovereign:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In sign, whereof, this arm, that hath reclaim'd

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To your obedience fifty fortresses,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Twelve cities and seven walled towns of strength,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Beside five hundred prisoners of esteem,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lets fall his sword before your highness' feet,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And with submissive loyalty of heart

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ascribes the glory of his conquest got

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: First to my God and next unto your grace.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is this the Lord Talbot, uncle Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That hath so long been resident in France?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yes, if it please your majesty, my liege.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Welcome, brave captain and victorious lord!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When I was young, as yet I am not old,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I do remember how my father said

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A stouter champion never handled sword.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Long since we were resolved of your truth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your faithful service and your toil in war;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Yet never have you tasted our reward,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or been reguerdon'd with so much as thanks,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Because till now we never saw your face:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore, stand up; and, for these good deserts,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We here create you Earl of Shrewsbury;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And in our coronation take your place.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but VERNON and BASSET

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Now, sir, to you, that were so hot at sea,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Disgracing of these colours that I wear

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: In honour of my noble Lord of York:

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Darest thou maintain the former words thou spakest?

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Yes, sir; as well as you dare patronage

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: The envious barking of your saucy tongue

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Against my lord the Duke of Somerset.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Sirrah, thy lord I honour as he is.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Why, what is he? as good a man as York.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Hark ye; not so: in witness, take ye that.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Villain, thou know'st the law of arms is such

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: That whoso draws a sword, 'tis present death,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Or else this blow should broach thy dearest blood.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: But I'll unto his majesty, and crave

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: I may have liberty to venge this wrong;

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: When thou shalt see I'll meet thee to thy cost.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Well, miscreant, I'll be there as soon as you;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And, after, meet you sooner than you would.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: SCENE I. Paris. A hall of state.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER, YORK, SUFFOLK, SOMERSET, WARWICK, TALBOT, EXETER, the Governor, of Paris, and others

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lord bishop, set the crown upon his head.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: God save King Henry, of that name the sixth!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now, governor of Paris, take your oath,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That you elect no other king but him;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Esteem none friends but such as are his friends,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And none your foes but such as shall pretend

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Malicious practises against his state:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This shall ye do, so help you righteous God!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter FASTOLFE

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: My gracious sovereign, as I rode from Calais,

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: To haste unto your coronation,

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: A letter was deliver'd to my hands,

speaker: FASTOLFE
text_entry: Writ to your grace from the Duke of Burgundy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shame to the Duke of Burgundy and thee!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I vow'd, base knight, when I did meet thee next,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To tear the garter from thy craven's leg,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Plucking it off

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Which I have done, because unworthily

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou wast installed in that high degree.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pardon me, princely Henry, and the rest

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This dastard, at the battle of Patay,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When but in all I was six thousand strong

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And that the French were almost ten to one,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Before we met or that a stroke was given,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Like to a trusty squire did run away:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In which assault we lost twelve hundred men;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Myself and divers gentlemen beside

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Were there surprised and taken prisoners.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then judge, great lords, if I have done amiss;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or whether that such cowards ought to wear

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This ornament of knighthood, yea or no.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To say the truth, this fact was infamous

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And ill beseeming any common man,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Much more a knight, a captain and a leader.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When first this order was ordain'd, my lords,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Knights of the garter were of noble birth,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Valiant and virtuous, full of haughty courage,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Such as were grown to credit by the wars;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not fearing death, nor shrinking for distress,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But always resolute in most extremes.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He then that is not furnish'd in this sort

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Doth but usurp the sacred name of knight,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Profaning this most honourable order,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And should, if I were worthy to be judge,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be quite degraded, like a hedge-born swain

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That doth presume to boast of gentle blood.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stain to thy countrymen, thou hear'st thy doom!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be packing, therefore, thou that wast a knight:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henceforth we banish thee, on pain of death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exit FASTOLFE

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And now, my lord protector, view the letter

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sent from our uncle Duke of Burgundy.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What means his grace, that he hath changed his style?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No more but, plain and bluntly, 'To the king!'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath he forgot he is his sovereign?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or doth this churlish superscription

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Pretend some alteration in good will?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What's here?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Reads

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'I have, upon especial cause,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Moved with compassion of my country's wreck,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Together with the pitiful complaints

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of such as your oppression feeds upon,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Forsaken your pernicious faction

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And join'd with Charles, the rightful King of France.'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O monstrous treachery! can this be so,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That in alliance, amity and oaths,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There should be found such false dissembling guile?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What! doth my uncle Burgundy revolt?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He doth, my lord, and is become your foe.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is that the worst this letter doth contain?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is the worst, and all, my lord, he writes.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, then, Lord Talbot there shall talk with him

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And give him chastisement for this abuse.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How say you, my lord? are you not content?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Content, my liege! yes, but that I am prevented,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I should have begg'd I might have been employ'd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then gather strength and march unto him straight:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let him perceive how ill we brook his treason

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And what offence it is to flout his friends.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I go, my lord, in heart desiring still

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You may behold confusion of your foes.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter VERNON and BASSET

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Grant me the combat, gracious sovereign.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And me, my lord, grant me the combat too.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This is my servant: hear him, noble prince.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And this is mine: sweet Henry, favour him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, lords; and give them leave to speak.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Say, gentlemen, what makes you thus exclaim?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And wherefore crave you combat? or with whom?

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: With him, my lord; for he hath done me wrong.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And I with him; for he hath done me wrong.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What is that wrong whereof you both complain?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First let me know, and then I'll answer you.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Crossing the sea from England into France,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: This fellow here, with envious carping tongue,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Upbraided me about the rose I wear;

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Saying, the sanguine colour of the leaves

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Did represent my master's blushing cheeks,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: When stubbornly he did repugn the truth

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: About a certain question in the law

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Argued betwixt the Duke of York and him;

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: With other vile and ignominious terms:

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: In confutation of which rude reproach

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: And in defence of my lord's worthiness,

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: I crave the benefit of law of arms.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And that is my petition, noble lord:

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: For though he seem with forged quaint conceit

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: To set a gloss upon his bold intent,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Yet know, my lord, I was provoked by him;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And he first took exceptions at this badge,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Pronouncing that the paleness of this flower

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Bewray'd the faintness of my master's heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will not this malice, Somerset, be left?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Your private grudge, my Lord of York, will out,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Though ne'er so cunningly you smother it.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Good Lord, what madness rules in brainsick men,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When for so slight and frivolous a cause

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Such factious emulations shall arise!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Good cousins both, of York and Somerset,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Quiet yourselves, I pray, and be at peace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let this dissension first be tried by fight,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And then your highness shall command a peace.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: The quarrel toucheth none but us alone;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: There is my pledge; accept it, Somerset.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Nay, let it rest where it began at first.

speaker: BASSET
text_entry: Confirm it so, mine honourable lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Confirm it so! Confounded be your strife!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And perish ye, with your audacious prate!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Presumptuous vassals, are you not ashamed

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With this immodest clamorous outrage

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To trouble and disturb the king and us?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And you, my lords, methinks you do not well

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To bear with their perverse objections;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Much less to take occasion from their mouths

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To raise a mutiny betwixt yourselves:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me persuade you take a better course.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: It grieves his highness: good my lords, be friends.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come hither, you that would be combatants:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henceforth I charge you, as you love our favour,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Quite to forget this quarrel and the cause.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And you, my lords, remember where we are,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In France, amongst a fickle wavering nation:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If they perceive dissension in our looks

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And that within ourselves we disagree,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How will their grudging stomachs be provoked

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To wilful disobedience, and rebel!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Beside, what infamy will there arise,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When foreign princes shall be certified

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That for a toy, a thing of no regard,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: King Henry's peers and chief nobility

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Destroy'd themselves, and lost the realm of France!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, think upon the conquest of my father,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My tender years, and let us not forego

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That for a trifle that was bought with blood

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me be umpire in this doubtful strife.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I see no reason, if I wear this rose,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Putting on a red rose

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That any one should therefore be suspicious

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I more incline to Somerset than York:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Both are my kinsmen, and I love them both:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: As well they may upbraid me with my crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Because, forsooth, the king of Scots is crown'd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But your discretions better can persuade

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than I am able to instruct or teach:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And therefore, as we hither came in peace,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So let us still continue peace and love.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Cousin of York, we institute your grace

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be our regent in these parts of France:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, good my Lord of Somerset, unite

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your troops of horsemen with his bands of foot;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, like true subjects, sons of your progenitors,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go cheerfully together and digest.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Your angry choler on your enemies.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ourself, my lord protector and the rest

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: After some respite will return to Calais;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From thence to England; where I hope ere long

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be presented, by your victories,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: With Charles, Alencon and that traitorous rout.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt all but YORK, WARWICK, EXETER and VERNON

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My Lord of York, I promise you, the king

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Prettily, methought, did play the orator.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And so he did; but yet I like it not,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In that he wears the badge of Somerset.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tush, that was but his fancy, blame him not;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I dare presume, sweet prince, he thought no harm.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: An if I wist he did,--but let it rest;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Other affairs must now be managed.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exeunt all but EXETER

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Well didst thou, Richard, to suppress thy voice;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For, had the passions of thy heart burst out,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: I fear we should have seen decipher'd there

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: More rancorous spite, more furious raging broils,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Than yet can be imagined or supposed.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But howsoe'er, no simple man that sees

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This jarring discord of nobility,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This shouldering of each other in the court,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This factious bandying of their favourites,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But that it doth presage some ill event.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: 'Tis much when sceptres are in children's hands;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But more when envy breeds unkind division;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: There comes the rain, there begins confusion.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. Before Bourdeaux.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, with trump and drum

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Go to the gates of Bourdeaux, trumpeter:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Summon their general unto the wall.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Trumpet sounds. Enter General and others, aloft

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: English John Talbot, captains, calls you forth,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Servant in arms to Harry King of England;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And thus he would: Open your city gates;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be humble to us; call my sovereign yours,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And do him homage as obedient subjects;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And I'll withdraw me and my bloody power:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, if you frown upon this proffer'd peace,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You tempt the fury of my three attendants,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lean famine, quartering steel, and climbing fire;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Who in a moment even with the earth

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall lay your stately and air-braving towers,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If you forsake the offer of their love.

speaker: General
text_entry: Thou ominous and fearful owl of death,

speaker: General
text_entry: Our nation's terror and their bloody scourge!

speaker: General
text_entry: The period of thy tyranny approacheth.

speaker: General
text_entry: On us thou canst not enter but by death;

speaker: General
text_entry: For, I protest, we are well fortified

speaker: General
text_entry: And strong enough to issue out and fight:

speaker: General
text_entry: If thou retire, the Dauphin, well appointed,

speaker: General
text_entry: Stands with the snares of war to tangle thee:

speaker: General
text_entry: On either hand thee there are squadrons pitch'd,

speaker: General
text_entry: To wall thee from the liberty of flight;

speaker: General
text_entry: And no way canst thou turn thee for redress,

speaker: General
text_entry: But death doth front thee with apparent spoil

speaker: General
text_entry: And pale destruction meets thee in the face.

speaker: General
text_entry: Ten thousand French have ta'en the sacrament

speaker: General
text_entry: To rive their dangerous artillery

speaker: General
text_entry: Upon no Christian soul but English Talbot.

speaker: General
text_entry: Lo, there thou stand'st, a breathing valiant man,

speaker: General
text_entry: Of an invincible unconquer'd spirit!

speaker: General
text_entry: This is the latest glory of thy praise

speaker: General
text_entry: That I, thy enemy, due thee withal;

speaker: General
text_entry: For ere the glass, that now begins to run,

speaker: General
text_entry: Finish the process of his sandy hour,

speaker: General
text_entry: These eyes, that see thee now well coloured,

speaker: General
text_entry: Shall see thee wither'd, bloody, pale and dead.

speaker: General
text_entry: Drum afar off

speaker: General
text_entry: Hark! hark! the Dauphin's drum, a warning bell,

speaker: General
text_entry: Sings heavy music to thy timorous soul;

speaker: General
text_entry: And mine shall ring thy dire departure out.

speaker: General
text_entry: Exeunt General,  and c

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He fables not; I hear the enemy:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Out, some light horsemen, and peruse their wings.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, negligent and heedless discipline!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How are we park'd and bounded in a pale,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A little herd of England's timorous deer,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Mazed with a yelping kennel of French curs!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If we be English deer, be then in blood;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not rascal-like, to fall down with a pinch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But rather, moody-mad and desperate stags,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Turn on the bloody hounds with heads of steel

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And make the cowards stand aloof at bay:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sell every man his life as dear as mine,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And they shall find dear deer of us, my friends.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: God and Saint George, Talbot and England's right,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Prosper our colours in this dangerous fight!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE III. Plains in Gascony.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter a Messenger that meets YORK. Enter YORK with trumpet and many Soldiers

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Are not the speedy scouts return'd again,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That dogg'd the mighty army of the Dauphin?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They are return'd, my lord, and give it out

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That he is march'd to Bourdeaux with his power,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To fight with Talbot: as he march'd along,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By your espials were discovered

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Two mightier troops than that the Dauphin led,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Which join'd with him and made their march for Bourdeaux.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A plague upon that villain Somerset,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That thus delays my promised supply

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of horsemen, that were levied for this siege!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Renowned Talbot doth expect my aid,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And I am lowted by a traitor villain

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And cannot help the noble chevalier:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: God comfort him in this necessity!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If he miscarry, farewell wars in France.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter Sir William LUCY

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Thou princely leader of our English strength,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Never so needful on the earth of France,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Spur to the rescue of the noble Talbot,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Who now is girdled with a waist of iron

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And hemm'd about with grim destruction:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: To Bourdeaux, warlike duke! to Bourdeaux, York!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Else, farewell Talbot, France, and England's honour.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O God, that Somerset, who in proud heart

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Doth stop my cornets, were in Talbot's place!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So should we save a valiant gentleman

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By forfeiting a traitor and a coward.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Mad ire and wrathful fury makes me weep,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That thus we die, while remiss traitors sleep.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: O, send some succor to the distress'd lord!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He dies, we lose; I break my warlike word;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: We mourn, France smiles; we lose, they daily get;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: All 'long of this vile traitor Somerset.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Then God take mercy on brave Talbot's soul;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And on his son young John, who two hours since

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: I met in travel toward his warlike father!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: This seven years did not Talbot see his son;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And now they meet where both their lives are done.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alas, what joy shall noble Talbot have

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To bid his young son welcome to his grave?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Away! vexation almost stops my breath,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That sunder'd friends greet in the hour of death.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lucy, farewell; no more my fortune can,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But curse the cause I cannot aid the man.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Maine, Blois, Poictiers, and Tours, are won away,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Long all of Somerset and his delay.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit, with his soldiers

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Thus, while the vulture of sedition

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Feeds in the bosom of such great commanders,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Sleeping neglection doth betray to loss

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The conquest of our scarce cold conqueror,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: That ever living man of memory,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Henry the Fifth: whiles they each other cross,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Lives, honours, lands and all hurry to loss.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: SCENE IV. Other plains in Gascony.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Enter SOMERSET, with his army; a Captain of TALBOT's with him

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: It is too late; I cannot send them now:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: This expedition was by York and Talbot

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Too rashly plotted: all our general force

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Might with a sally of the very town

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Be buckled with: the over-daring Talbot

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Hath sullied all his gloss of former honour

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: By this unheedful, desperate, wild adventure:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York set him on to fight and die in shame,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That, Talbot dead, great York might bear the name.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Here is Sir William Lucy, who with me

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Set from our o'ermatch'd forces forth for aid.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Enter Sir William LUCY

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: How now, Sir William! whither were you sent?

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Whither, my lord? from bought and sold Lord Talbot;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Who, ring'd about with bold adversity,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Cries out for noble York and Somerset,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: To beat assailing death from his weak legions:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And whiles the honourable captain there

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Drops bloody sweat from his war-wearied limbs,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And, in advantage lingering, looks for rescue,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: You, his false hopes, the trust of England's honour,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Keep off aloof with worthless emulation.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Let not your private discord keep away

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The levied succors that should lend him aid,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: While he, renowned noble gentleman,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Yields up his life unto a world of odds:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Orleans the Bastard, Charles, Burgundy,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Alencon, Reignier, compass him about,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And Talbot perisheth by your default.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York set him on; York should have sent him aid.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And York as fast upon your grace exclaims;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Swearing that you withhold his levied host,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Collected for this expedition.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: York lies; he might have sent and had the horse;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: I owe him little duty, and less love;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And take foul scorn to fawn on him by sending.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: The fraud of England, not the force of France,

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Hath now entrapp'd the noble-minded Talbot:

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Never to England shall he bear his life;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: But dies, betray'd to fortune by your strife.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Come, go; I will dispatch the horsemen straight:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Within six hours they will be at his aid.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Too late comes rescue: he is ta'en or slain;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: For fly he could not, if he would have fled;

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: And fly would Talbot never, though he might.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If he be dead, brave Talbot, then adieu!

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: His fame lives in the world, his shame in you.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: SCENE V. The English camp near Bourdeaux.

speaker: LUCY
text_entry: Enter TALBOT and JOHN his son

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O young John Talbot! I did send for thee

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To tutor thee in stratagems of war,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That Talbot's name might be in thee revived

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: When sapless age and weak unable limbs

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Should bring thy father to his drooping chair.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, O malignant and ill-boding stars!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now thou art come unto a feast of death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A terrible and unavoided danger:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Therefore, dear boy, mount on my swiftest horse;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And I'll direct thee how thou shalt escape

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: By sudden flight: come, dally not, be gone.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Is my name Talbot? and am I your son?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: And shall I fly? O if you love my mother,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Dishonour not her honourable name,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To make a bastard and a slave of me!

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: The world will say, he is not Talbot's blood,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: That basely fled when noble Talbot stood.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Fly, to revenge my death, if I be slain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: He that flies so will ne'er return again.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If we both stay, we both are sure to die.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Then let me stay; and, father, do you fly:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Your loss is great, so your regard should be;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: My worth unknown, no loss is known in me.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Upon my death the French can little boast;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: In yours they will, in you all hopes are lost.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Flight cannot stain the honour you have won;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: But mine it will, that no exploit have done:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: You fled for vantage, everyone will swear;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: But, if I bow, they'll say it was for fear.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: There is no hope that ever I will stay,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: If the first hour I shrink and run away.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Here on my knee I beg mortality,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Rather than life preserved with infamy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall all thy mother's hopes lie in one tomb?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Ay, rather than I'll shame my mother's womb.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Upon my blessing, I command thee go.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: To fight I will, but not to fly the foe.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Part of thy father may be saved in thee.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: No part of him but will be shame in me.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou never hadst renown, nor canst not lose it.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Yes, your renowned name: shall flight abuse it?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thy father's charge shall clear thee from that stain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: You cannot witness for me, being slain.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: If death be so apparent, then both fly.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And leave my followers here to fight and die?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My age was never tainted with such shame.

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: And shall my youth be guilty of such blame?

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: No more can I be sever'd from your side,

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Than can yourself yourself in twain divide:

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: Stay, go, do what you will, the like do I;

speaker: JOHN TALBOT
text_entry: For live I will not, if my father die.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then here I take my leave of thee, fair son,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Born to eclipse thy life this afternoon.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Come, side by side together live and die.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And soul with soul from France to heaven fly.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE VI. A field of battle.

speaker: TALBOT
